title: In the Global Race for Rare Earth Mineral Dominance, One Company Believes the US Already has Everything it Needs Right Here
description: American Resources Corporation has transformed the shuttered Thompson Electronics plant into a high-tech manufacturing hub tackling one of the most urgent challenges facing the United States today: rare earth independence.
content:
In a quiet corner of eastern Kentucky, an abandoned television factory once left for dead is roaring back to life. But it’s not TVs being assembled inside.

American Resources Corporation has transformed the shuttered Thompson Electronics plant into a high-tech manufacturing hub tackling one of the most urgent challenges facing the United States today: rare earth independence.

“We’re doing what few people thought could be done — taking discarded material and converting it into pure, high-value rare earth elements, right here in America,” said CEO Mark Jensen.

Led by his vision, American Resources is leveraging what’s already right here in the US —reclaiming rare earths from industrial waste and end-of-life products—using proprietary technology that separates and purifies these valuable materials.

His excitement is infectious. The company he leads has a 15-year head start in an industry that barely exists domestically. American Resources Corporation is a pioneer in extracting and refining rare earth elements—like neodymium, praseodymium, and dysprosium—from recycled materials. These elements power everything from smartphones to electric vehicles and missile systems.

The company is rewriting conventional wisdom: that the U.S. doesn’t manufacture anything anymore, that Americans are completely reliant on foreign imports—especially from China. And it's not doing it by ripping up landscapes which is what routinely happens in mining rare earths overseas and which is widely considered to be an environmentally dirty business. It's using what’s already here, utilizing existing raw materials to power our future both cleanly and efficiently.

At the heart of this innovation is the company’s ReElement process, now operating at commercial scale. It produces both c-grade and magnet-grade rare earths from recycled feedstock at the Kentucky facility.

So quietly has this process been developed that many—including potential partners—didn’t even know it existed. That changed when major players from DC to Silicon Valley started to take notice, largely due to current tensions with China which exports 80% of the United States’ rare earth minerals. The concept of producing high-purity rare earths in America, outside of foreign influence, has been a front and center priority of both the current administration and across party lines in Congress.

The company’s momentum is unfolding in tandem with broader shifts in global trade. With new tariffs imposed by the federal government that have increased costs on imported rare earths and other critical materials, US companies have had to rethink their sourcing. The renewed focus on domestic manufacturing has most major US technology companies reassessing where and how they produce these key elements.

With the infrastructure and technology in place, the company seems well positioned to meet demand. The Kentucky facility, rebuilt from the ground up, serves as both a working prototype and a symbol of possibility. The materials it produces may soon power fighter jets, satellites, electric vehicles, and next-gen technologies.

For many Americans, the idea of turning industrial waste into defense-grade materials sounds far-fetched. Jensen believes that the idea that we have to go overseas for these materials is false. “The United States has all the raw ingredients it needs—and we’re proving that every day. We’re not dependent. We’re underdeveloped,” states Jensen. And that’s the distinction. And also the opportunity.
summary: American Resources Corporation, a company that specializes in extracting and refining rare earth elements from recycled materials, has transformed a former television factory into a high-tech manufacturing hub in eastern Kentucky. CEO Mark Jensen believes that the US already has everything it needs to achieve rare earth independence and is using discarded material to produce high-purity rare earths. The company's ReElement process, which produces both c-grade and magnet-grade rare earth from recycled feedstock, could power everything from smartphones to electric vehicles and missile systems. This innovation has been overlooked due to current tensions with China, which exports 80% of the US’s rare earth minerals. This shift in global trade is seen as a response to new tariffs imposed by the federal government that have increased costs on imported rare materials.
shortSummary: American Resources Corporation is revolutionizing rare earth production using recycled materials, leveraging existing technologies, amid growing global demand for these highly valuable materials.
